title: 'I would love another one': Candice Warner reveals her exciting family news
text:
Candice Warner, 34, has revealed that she and Cricket star husband David, 33, plan on having more children.

Speaking to The Daily Telegraph on Tuesday, mother-of-three Candice revealed the pair would love to expand their brood further.

'I would love another one,' Candice told the publication.

'I would love another one': Candice Warner and cricketer husband David (both pictured) have revealed their exciting family news during an interview with The Daily Telegraph on Tuesday

She explained the couple hasn't set down any firm plans, with the family only welcoming baby Isla Rose four months ago.

She went on to add that her cricketer husband David is still gaining back his career following the ball tampering scandal.

'David is still heavily in his career, which means he is away a lot of the time and three kids on my own is a lot and three kids travelling is a lot.'

The couple already share three children together: Ivy Mae, five, Indi Rae, three, and Isla Rose, four months.

Family: 'David is still heavily in his career, which means he is away a lot of the time and three kids on my own is a lot and three kids travelling is a lot' she said. Here with family

Former professional ironwoman Candice also revealed she is finished with her own sporting career.

'I would definitely look at doing another marathon or maybe a triathlon somewhere down the line but at the moment, nothing professional ever again,' she added.

It comes after Candice revealed the huge toll David's ball-tampering scandal took on the family during an interview with Stellar magazine on Sunday.

Backburner: 'I would definitely look at doing another marathon or maybe a triathlon somewhere down the line but at the moment, nothing professional ever again,' she said

The couple have been through two miscarriages in 15 months since David's cheating incident in Cape Town in March 2018.

'Looking back, it was a very horrific time,' she told the publication.

'We had two miscarriages. It definitely took a toll on my body. It was heartbreaking. I thought, 'What more can be taken from me?'

Hardship: 'Looking back, it was a very horrific time,' Candice told Stellar magazine previously after the ball-tampering incident and the two miscarriages the couple suffered

Candice made the decision to be the 'strength and rock' for her husband and their two girls after David was hit with a ban from the sport for a year for his role in the ball-tampering ordeal.

She decided to look at the positive aspects of Warner's ban - in that his doting daughters could have an abundance of 'daddy time' with their father.

'David and I now look at each other and say, 'How did we get through that?',' she added. 'But we did. We now know for sure that nothing will ever break us.'

Tough: 'David and I now look at each other and say, 'How did we get through that?',' she added. 'But we did. We now know for sure that nothing will ever break us'

Now, Candice says their lives 'couldn't be any better', adding the family are more grateful than ever before of everything they have.

'For us, life is about family and we are so blessed to have three healthy girls. We are a very solid unit. We are a team,' she added.

David made a stunning return to cricket since the ban was lifted this year.

Scandal: David (pictured), former Australian captain Steve Smith and player Cameron Bancroft were slapped with bans for conspiring to cheat against South Africa in March 2018

Candice previously opened up about her first miscarriage in an interview with the Australian Women's Weekly in May 2018.

'The miscarriage was a tragic consequence, a heartbreaking end to a horror tour,' she told the publication at the time.

'Like so many families who've experience a miscarriage, it's just really sad,' she continued.
description: Candice Warner, 34, has revealed that she and Cricket star husband David, 33, plan on having more children.
authors: Caleb Taylor For Daily Mail Australia
